title: Consent & Attribution
description: Check if consent was given or is required, and what attribution obligations exist.

q2b.text: What do you want to use?

options.label: Voice / likeness of a real person
Synthetic voice trained on real person
Fully synthetic, no real person reference

Melody or hook from existing song

output-a1.title: Found in Dataset
output-a1.context: Your work was found in a known training dataset
requirements: Check if you gave consent (platform ToS, distribution agreements)
Review any contracts with distributors for AI/ML clauses
risks: Your consent may have been buried in ToS you agreed to
Removal may not be possible if model already trained
actions: File GDPR data subject access request (EU) to demand information
Request removal under GDPR Article 17 (right to erasure)
Contact dataset maintainer directly
Consider legal consultation if commercial harm

sources.title: Have I Been Trained
sources.description: Search for your work in AI datasets

output-a2.title: Suspected Use
output-a2.context: You suspect your work was used but have no proof
risks: Difficult to prove without dataset access
AI companies often don't disclose training data
actions: Search Have I Been Trained (haveibeentrained.com)
Check Spawning.ai for opt-out tools
Review your distributor's AI policy (DistroKid, TuneCore, etc.)
Document timeline of your releases vs. model training dates
File GDPR access request to AI company directly

output-a3.title: AI Output Sounds Like Your Work
output-a3.context: An AI-generated output resembles your work
requirements: Understand the difference between training data issues and output similarity
risks: Similarity alone doesn't prove your work was in training data
Copyright infringement claims for AI output are legally untested
Burden of proof is on you
actions: Document the AI output (save file, note date, tool used)
Compare side-by-side with your original
Determine: is this a copyright claim (output) or training data issue (input)?
For copyright: consult IP lawyer
For training data: follow suspected use path

output-a4.title: Getting Started
output-a4.context: Not sure where to begin checking
risks: Your work may have been included via distributor agreements
Opt-out may not be retroactive
actions: Start with Have I Been Trained (haveibeentrained.com)
Check your distributor's AI/ML policy
Review any contracts for AI training clauses
Register with Spawning.ai to set preferences for future use
Consider adding AI training opt-out to your metadata

output-b-voice-1.title: Using Real, Identifiable Voice
output-b-voice-1.context: You want to use a real person's identifiable voice
requirements: Consent must be specific to your use case
risks: Right of publicity laws vary by jurisdiction
High risk if used commercially without consent
Consent for one use doesn't cover other uses
actions: Obtain written consent specifying: scope, duration, territory, compensation
Include AI/synthetic use explicitly in consent
Document the consent chain
Check platform policies (streaming services may have additional rules)

sources.title: US Right of Publicity
sources.description: State-level laws (CA, TN, NY most relevant)

output-b-voice-2.title: Using Synthetic Voice Trained on Real Person
output-b-voice-2.context: Using AI-generated voice based on a real person
requirements: Same consent obligations as real voice
Disclosure required under EU AI Act Article 52
risks: Deepfake regulations are tightening globally
Platform ToS may prohibit synthetic voices
Reputational risk even if technically legal
actions: Obtain consent from the original person
Disclose synthetic nature in your content
Check AI tool's ToS for restrictions
Check distribution platform policies
Document your consent and disclosure chain

output-b-voice-3.title: Using Fully Synthetic Voice
output-b-voice-3.context: Using AI voice with no real person reference
requirements: Disclosure may still be required for some platforms
risks: AI tool may claim ownership/royalties
Some platforms require AI disclosure regardless
Lower legal risk but not zero
actions: Review AI tool's ToS for ownership and usage rights
Check if attribution to AI tool is required
Check distribution platform policies on AI-generated content
Consider voluntary disclosure for trust

output-b-recording-1.title: Sampling Released Track
output-b-recording-1.context: Using a sample from a commercially released recording
risks: No fair use assumption for music sampling in most jurisdictions
Uncleared samples can result in lawsuits, takedowns, profit seizure
Even short samples can be infringing
actions: Identify rights holders (label for master, publisher for composition)
Contact for clearance before release
Negotiate terms: fee, royalty split, credit
Get clearance in writing
Consider re-recording to avoid master clearance (still need publishing)

output-b-recording-2.title: Using Stems/Multitracks
output-b-recording-2.context: Using stems or multitrack files from a released recording
risks: Common misconception that stems are freer to use
Same legal risk as sampling the master
actions: Follow same process as sampling released track
Contact label and publisher for clearance

output-b-recording-3.title: Using Sample Library Sounds
output-b-recording-3.context: Using sounds from a sample library
requirements: Many libraries now have AI-specific clauses
risks: License may not cover AI training or AI-assisted production
Some licenses require attribution
Royalty-free ≠ rights-free
actions: Read the full license agreement
Check for AI/ML exclusions
Check attribution requirements
Keep proof of license
When in doubt, contact the library

output-b-recording-4.title: Using AI-Generated Sound
output-b-recording-4.context: Using AI-generated audio trained on existing recordings
requirements: Understand you inherit the training data's legal ambiguity
risks: If AI trained on unlicensed data, your output may be legally risky
Provenance often unclear
Legal landscape is evolving
actions: Check AI tool's documentation on training data
Look for model cards or provenance statements
Consider 'ethical AI' alternatives with documented consent
Disclose AI use in your credits
Monitor legal developments

output-b-comp-1.title: Using Melody or Hook
output-b-comp-1.context: Using a melody or hook from an existing song
risks: Melody is one of the most protected elements
Even similar melodies can trigger infringement claims
actions: Contact publisher for clearance
Consider writing original melody instead
If inspired by, ensure it's sufficiently different

output-b-comp-2.title: Using Chord Progression
output-b-comp-2.context: Using a chord progression from an existing song
risks: Low legal risk for chord progressions alone
Risk increases if combined with similar melody, rhythm, or arrangement
actions: Chord progressions alone are typically safe
Avoid combining with other similar elements
Document your creative process

output-b-comp-3.title: Using Lyrics
output-b-comp-3.context: Using lyrics from an existing song
risks: Even short phrases can be protected if distinctive
Quoting lyrics without clearance is infringement
actions: Contact publisher for clearance
Write original lyrics
If quoting, ensure you have permission or it qualifies as fair use (rare for music)

output-b-comp-4.title: Using AI-Generated Composition
risks: Ownership of AI-generated compositions is legally unclear
Some jurisdictions require human authorship for copyright
Training data may include copyrighted compositions
actions: Review AI tool's ToS for ownership claims
Check if tool discloses training data sources
Add human creative input to strengthen your claim
Document your creative process
Consider voluntary disclosure

output-c-pretrained.title: Using Pre-trained Model
output-c-pretrained.context: Integrating a pre-trained AI model in your product
risks: You may inherit legal risk from training data
License may restrict commercial use
Provenance often unclear
actions: Read model license carefully
Check for model card or training data documentation
Assess if training data had proper consent
Consider indemnification if licensing from vendor
Document your due diligence

output-c-platform.title: Building a Platform
output-c-platform.context: Building a platform where users upload or generate content
requirements: Clear ToS covering AI training use
risks: Liability for user-uploaded infringing content
GDPR compliance for EU users
Evolving regulations
actions: Draft ToS that explicitly addresses AI training
Implement clear consent flows
Provide opt-out mechanism for AI training
Set up DMCA/takedown process
Consider content moderation for synthetic media
Consult legal counsel

output-c-training-1.title: Training on Licensed Dataset
output-c-training-1.context: Using properly licensed data for training
risks: Older licenses may not cover AI training
License may have restrictions on output use
actions: Document the license and keep records
Verify license explicitly covers AI/ML training use
Check for output restrictions
Be prepared to prove provenance if challenged
Consider transparency statement in your documentation

output-c-training-2.title: Training on Scraped Data
output-c-training-2.context: Using data scraped from the public internet
requirements: Opt-out mechanisms required under EU AI Act
risks: High legal risk in EU (GDPR, EU AI Act)
Public ≠ free to use for training
Class action lawsuits emerging
actions: Implement and respect opt-out mechanisms
Check robots.txt and ToS of source sites
Consider switching to licensed data
Document your data sources
Monitor regulatory developments
Consult legal counsel

output-c-training-3.title: Training on User-Uploaded Content
output-c-training-3.context: Using content uploaded by your users for training
risks: Users may not understand what they're consenting to
GDPR data subject rights apply
Reputational risk if perceived as exploitative
actions: Update ToS to explicitly cover AI training
Implement clear, informed consent flow
Consider opt-in vs opt-out (opt-in is safer)
Provide mechanism to withdraw consent
Be transparent about how data is used
Consider revenue sharing or other value exchange

output-c-training-4.title: Training on Mixed Sources
output-c-training-4.context: Using a combination of data sources for training
risks: Weakest link determines overall risk
Harder to prove provenance
Contamination from unlicensed data
actions: Audit and document all data sources
Assess each source's license/consent status
Remove or replace high-risk sources
Consider data auditing tools
Prepare provenance documentation
Consult legal counsel
